During locoregional anaesthesia, the local anaesthetics used act on nerve conduction by blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels. The action potential can no longer be conducted along the nerve fibre.

question.title: What is the primary mechanism of action of local anaesthetics during locoregional anaesthesia?
question.description: The local anaesthetics used act on nerve conduction by blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels. The action potential can no longer be conducted along the nerve fibre.

option_a.title: Blocking potassium channels
option_a.description: Local anaesthetics block potassium channels, preventing the repolarization phase of the action potential.

option_b.title: Blocking calcium channels
option_b.description: Local anaesthetics block calcium channels, reducing the influx of calcium ions and preventing the depolarization phase of the action potential.

option_c.title: Blocking voltage-dependent sodium channels
option_c.description: Local anaesthetics block voltage-dependent sodium channels, preventing the generation of action potentials along the nerve fibre.

option_d.title: Blocking chloride channels
option_d.description: Local anaesthetics block chloride channels, altering the resting membrane potential and preventing the action potential.
